newsitem.title: INDIA: GOLD-India seen initiating more liberal policy.
newsitem.headline: GOLD-India seen initiating more liberal policy.

text.p: India, the world's largest consumer of gold, is expected to further liberalise imports as part of economic reform and to boost jewellery exports, traders said on Monday.
Bullion and jewellery trade members who attended a gold seminar at the weekend in New Delhi said they expect a more liberal gold policy in the the next few months.
"There are indications the government will further liberalise its gold policy," said Bombay Bullion Association president Makhan Lal Damani.
He said measures under consideration included allowing free imports of gold and resumption of forward trading in bullion, banned in 1962.
"These measures may take some time to materialise," Damani said. "They will boost gold imports and jewellery exports."
In his address to the seminar, S.S. Tarapore, who heads a panel on how to achieve the rupee's full float on the capital account, called for free gold imports.
"... I have no hesitation in saying that the import of gold should be placed under open general licence (OGL)," he said.
Y.V. Reddy, deputy governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) said more banks would be allowed to import gold.
At present expatriate Indians are allowed to import up to 10 kgs gold every six months, subject to a duty of 220 rupees per 10 grammes.
Currently, the government-run State Bank of India (SBI) and state-run trading company MMTC Ltd are allowed to import gold for supplies to jewellers.
Damani said he expected India's gold imports to touch 500 tonnes in 1997/98 (April/March) against 409 in the previous year.
V.M Kapoor, president of the Bombay-based Gold Jewellery Exporters' Association, said six more banks would soon start supplying gold.
"These banks can set up gold accounts, buy and sell gold and give gold loans," he said.
"But free imports under OGL may take some time to materialise as the issue is linked to the rupee's full convertibility on the capital account," Kapoor said.
"Nothing appears concrete at the moment. But we understand the government is keen on ensuring an uninterrupted supply of gold to jewellery exporters," Kapoor said.
Indian gold jewellery exports are expected to touch $850 million in 1997/98 against $745 million the previous year and reach $1.5 billion by the turn of the century.
In the week to Monday in Bombay, gold gained a modest five rupees per 10 grammes to 4,530 rupees and dealers expect prices to remain firm in the coming days ahead of a four-month festival season.
In neighbouring Pakistan, prices were weaker and were likely to slip further in line with a fall in international prices and depressed domestic demand.
"Demand for gold has fallen in the past few months because of the country's weak economic conditions," dealer Farooq Qureshi said. "Falling gold rates abroad also affected domestic market."
Dealers in Dubai, the market that supplies gold to India and Pakistan, welcomed Indian officials' comments indicating a further relaxation in the gold import policy.

"In the short and medium term liberalisation is going to be positive for Dubai," said Rolf Schneebeli, the World Gold Council's chief executive for the Middle East and Indian-subcontinent based in Dubai.
